segment.source: 1 Introduction
segment.target: 1 Introduction

segment.source: Developing a secure app can be a challenge.
segment.target: Developing a secure app can be a challenge.

segment.source: In today’s fast-paced world of mobile, social, cloud, and complex enterprise apps, customers expect apps to become available and updated faster than ever.
segment.target: In today’s fast-paced world of mobile, social, cloud, and complex enterprise apps, customers expect apps to become available and updated faster than ever.

segment.source: They also use many types of devices, further adding to the complexity of creating app experiences.
segment.target: They also use many types of devices, further adding to the complexity of creating app experiences.

segment.source: If you build for the Windows 10 Universal Windows Platform (UWP), that could include the traditional list of desktops, laptops, tablets, and mobile devices; in addition to a growing list of new devices spanning the Internet of Things, Xbox One, Microsoft Surface Hub, and HoloLens.
segment.target: If you build for the Windows 10 Universal Windows Platform (UWP), that could include the traditional list of desktops, laptops, tablets, and mobile devices; in addition to a growing list of new devices spanning the Internet of Things, Xbox One, Microsoft Surface Hub, and HoloLens.

segment.source: As the developer, you must ensure your apps communicate and store data securely, across all the platforms or devices involved.
segment.target: As the developer, you must ensure your apps communicate and store data securely, across all the platforms or devices involved.

segment.source: Here are some of the benefits of utilizing Windows 10 security features.
segment.target: Here are some of the benefits of utilizing Windows 10 security features.

segment.source: You will have standardized security across all devices that support Windows 10, by using consistent APIs for security components and technologies.
segment.target: You will have standardized security across all devices that support Windows 10, by using consistent APIs for security components and technologies.

segment.source: You write, test, and maintain less code than you would if you implemented custom code to cover these security scenarios.
segment.target: You write, test, and maintain less code than you would if you implemented custom code to cover these security scenarios.

segment.source: Your apps become more stable and secure because you use the operating system to control how the app accesses its resources and local or remote system resources.
segment.target: Your apps become more stable and secure because you use the operating system to control how the app accesses its resources and local or remote system resources.

segment.source: During authentication, the identity of a user requesting access to a particular service is validated.
segment.target: During authentication, the identity of a user requesting access to a particular service is validated.

segment.source: Microsoft Passport and Windows Hello are the components in Windows 10 that help create a more secure authentication mechanism in Windows apps.
segment.target: Microsoft Passport and Windows Hello are the components in Windows 10 that help create a more secure authentication mechanism in Windows apps.

segment.source: With them, you can use a Personal Identification Number (PIN), or biometrics such as the user’s fingerprints, face, or iris to implement multi-factor authentication for your apps.
segment.target: With them, you can use a Personal Identification Number (PIN), or biometrics such as the user’s fingerprints, face, or iris to implement multi-factor authentication for your apps.

segment.source: Data-in-flight refers to the connection and the messages transferred across it.
segment.target: Data-in-flight refers to the connection and the messages transferred across it.

segment.source: An example of this is retrieving data from a remote server using web services.
segment.target: An example of this is retrieving data from a remote server using web services.

segment.source: The use of Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) and Secure Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTPS) ensures the security of the connection.
segment.target: The use of Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) and Secure Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTPS) ensures the security of the connection.

segment.source: Preventing intermediary parties from accessing these messages, or unauthorized apps from communicating with the web services, is key to securing data in flight.
segment.target: Preventing intermediary parties from accessing these messages, or unauthorized apps from communicating with the web services, is key to securing data in flight.

segment.source: Lastly, data-at-rest relates to data residing in memory or on storage media.
segment.target: Lastly, data-at-rest relates to data residing in memory or on storage media.

segment.source: Windows 10 has an app model that prevents unauthorized data access between apps, and offers encryption APIs to further secure data on the device.
segment.target: Windows 10 has an app model that prevents unauthorized data access between apps, and offers encryption APIs to further secure data on the device.

segment.source: A feature called Credential Locker can be used to securely store user credentials on the device, with the operating system preventing other apps from accessing them.
segment.target: A feature called Credential Locker can be used to securely store user credentials on the device, with the operating system preventing other apps from accessing them.

segment.source: 2 Authentication Factors
segment.target: 2 Authentication Factors

segment.source: To protect data, the person requesting access to it must be identified and authorized to access the data resources they request.
segment.target: To protect data, the person requesting access to it must be identified and authorized to access the data resources they request.

segment.source: The process of identifying a user is called authentication, and determining access privileges to a resource is called authorization.
segment.target: The process of identifying a user is called authentication, and determining access privileges to a resource is called authorization.

segment.source: These are closely related operations, and to the user they might be indistinguishable.
segment.target: These are closely related operations, and to the user they might be indistinguishable.

segment.source: They can be relatively simple or complex operations, depending on many factors: for example, whether the data resides on one server or is distributed across many systems.
segment.target: They can be relatively simple or complex operations, depending on many factors: for example, whether the data resides on one server or is distributed across many systems.

segment.source: The server providing the authentication and authorization services is referred to as the identity provider.
segment.target: The server providing the authentication and authorization services is referred to as the identity provider.

segment.source: To authenticate themselves with a particular service and/or app, the user employs credentials made up of something they know, something they have, and/or something they are.
segment.target: To authenticate themselves with a particular service and/or app, the user employs credentials made up of something they know, something they have, and/or something they are.

segment.source: Each of these are called authentication factors.
segment.target: Each of these are called authentication factors.

segment.source: Something the user knows is usually a password, but it can also be a personal identification number (PIN) or a “secret” question-and-answer pair.
segment.target: Something the user knows is usually a password, but it can also be a personal identification number (PIN) or a “secret” question-and-answer pair.

segment.source: Something the user has is most often a hardware memory device such as a USB stick containing the authentication data unique to the user.
segment.target: Something the user has is most often a hardware memory device such as a USB stick containing the authentication data unique to the user.

segment.source: Something the user is often encompasses their fingerprints, but there are increasingly popular factors like the user’s speech, facial, ocular (eye) characteristics, or patterns of behavior.
segment.target: Something the user is often encompasses their fingerprints, but there are increasingly popular factors like the user’s speech, facial, ocular (eye) characteristics, or patterns of behavior.

segment.source: When stored as data, these measurements are called biometrics.
segment.target: When stored as data, these measurements are called biometrics.

segment.source: A password created by the user is an authentication factor in itself, but it often isn’t sufficient; anyone who knows the password can impersonate the user who owns it.
segment.target: A password created by the user is an authentication factor in itself, but it often isn’t sufficient; anyone who knows the password can impersonate the user who owns it.

segment.source: A smart card can provide a higher level of security, but it might be stolen, lost, or misplaced.
segment.target: A smart card can provide a higher level of security, but it might be stolen, lost, or misplaced.

segment.source: A system that can authenticate a user by their fingerprint or by an ocular scan might provide the highest and most convenient level of security, but it requires expensive and specialized hardware (for example, an Intel RealSense camera for facial recognition) that might not be available to all users.
segment.target: A system that can authenticate a user by their fingerprint or by an ocular scan might provide the highest and most convenient level of security, but it requires expensive and specialized hardware (for example, an Intel RealSense camera for facial recognition) that might not be available to all users.

segment.source: Designing the method of authentication used by a system is a complex and important aspect of data security.
segment.target: Designing the method of authentication used by a system is a complex and important aspect of data security.

segment.source: In general, the greater number of factors you use in authentication, the more secure the system is.
segment.target: In general, the greater number of factors you use in authentication, the more secure the system is.

segment.source: At the same time, authentication must be usable.
segment.target: At the same time, authentication must be usable.

segment.source: A user will usually log in many times a day, so the process must be fast.
segment.target: A user will usually log in many times a day, so the process must be fast.

segment.source: Your choice of authentication type is a trade-off between security and ease of use; single-factor authentication is the least secure and easiest to use, and multi-factor authentication becomes more secure, but more complex as more factors are added.
segment.target: Your choice of authentication type is a trade-off between security and ease of use; single-factor authentication is the least secure and easiest to use, and multi-factor authentication becomes more secure, but more complex as more factors are added.

segment.source: 2.1 Single-factor authentication
segment.target: 2.1 Single-factor authentication

segment.source: This form of authentication is based on a single user credential.
segment.target: This form of authentication is based on a single user credential.

segment.source: This is usually a password, but it could also be a personal identification number (PIN).
segment.target: This is usually a password, but it could also be a personal identification number (PIN).

segment.source: Here’s the process of single-factor authentication.
segment.target: Here’s the process of single-factor authentication.

segment.source: The user provides their username and password to the identity provider.
segment.target: The user provides their username and password to the identity provider.

segment.source: The identity provider is the server process that verifies the identity of the user.
segment.target: The identity provider is the server process that verifies the identity of the user.

segment.source: The identity provider checks whether the username and password are the same as those stored in the system.
segment.target: The identity provider checks whether the username and password are the same as those stored in the system.

segment.source: In most cases, the password will be encrypted, providing additional security so that others cannot read it.
segment.target: In most cases, the password will be encrypted, providing additional security so that others cannot read it.

segment.source: The identity provider returns an authentication status that indicates whether the authentication was successful.
segment.target: The identity provider returns an authentication status that indicates whether the authentication was successful.

segment.source: If successful, data exchange begins.
segment.target: If successful, data exchange begins.

segment.source: If unsuccessful, the user must be re-authenticated.
segment.target: If unsuccessful, the user must be re-authenticated.

segment.source: 2.1.1 Web authentication broker
segment.target: 2.1.1 Web authentication broker

segment.source: As previously discussed, one of the challenges with password authentication for an IT department is the added overhead of managing the base of usernames/passwords, reset mechanisms, etc. An increasingly popular option is to rely on third-party identity providers that offer authentication through OAuth, an open standard for authentication.
segment.target: As previously discussed, one of the challenges with password authentication for an IT department is the added overhead of managing the base of usernames/passwords, reset mechanisms, etc. An increasingly popular option is to rely on third-party identity providers that offer authentication through OAuth, an open standard for authentication.

segment.source: Using OAuth, IT departments can effectively "outsource" the complexity of maintaining a database with usernames and passwords, reset password functionality, etc. to a third party identity provider like Facebook, Twitter or Microsoft.
segment.target: Using OAuth, IT departments can effectively "outsource" the complexity of maintaining a database with usernames and passwords, reset password functionality, etc. to a third party identity provider like Facebook, Twitter or Microsoft.

segment.source: Users have complete control over their identity on these platforms, but apps can request a token from the provider, after the user is authenticated and with their consent, which can be used to authorize authenticated users.
segment.target: Users have complete control over their identity on these platforms, but apps can request a token from the provider, after the user is authenticated and with their consent, which can be used to authorize authenticated users.

segment.source: 2.2 Multi-factor authentication
segment.target: 2.2 Multi-factor authentication

segment.source: Multi-factor authentication makes use of more than one authentication factor.
segment.target: Multi-factor authentication makes use of more than one authentication factor.

segment.source: Usually, "something you know," such as a password, is combined with "something you have," which can be a mobile phone or a smart card.
segment.target: Usually, "something you know," such as a password, is combined with "something you have," which can be a mobile phone or a smart card.

segment.source: Even if an attacker discovers the user’s password, the account is still inaccessible without the device or card.
segment.target: Even if an attacker discovers the user’s password, the account is still inaccessible without the device or card.

segment.source: And if only the device or card is compromised, it is not useful to the attacker without the password.
segment.target: And if only the device or card is compromised, it is not useful to the attacker without the password.

segment.source: Multi-factor authentication is therefore more secure, but also more complex, than single-factor authentication.
segment.target: Multi-factor authentication is therefore more secure, but also more complex, than single-factor authentication.

segment.source: Services that use multi-factor authentication will often give the user a choice in how they receive the second credential.
segment.target: Services that use multi-factor authentication will often give the user a choice in how they receive the second credential.

segment.source: An example of this type of authentication is a commonly used process where a verification code is sent to the user’s mobile phone using SMS.
segment.target: An example of this type of authentication is a commonly used process where a verification code is sent to the user’s mobile phone using SMS.

segment.source: The user provides their username and password to the identity provider.
segment.target: The user provides their username and password to the identity provider.

segment.source: The identity provider verifies the username and password as in single-factor authorization, and then looks up the user’s mobile phone number stored in the system.
segment.target: The identity provider verifies the username and password as in single-factor authorization, and then looks up the user’s mobile phone number stored in the system.

segment.source: The server sends an SMS message containing a generated verification code to the user’s mobile phone.
segment.target: The server sends an SMS message containing a generated verification code to the user’s mobile phone.

segment.source: The user provides the verification code to the identity provider; through a form presented to the user.
segment.target: The user provides the verification code to the identity provider; through a form presented to the user.

segment.source: The identity provider returns an authentication status that indicates whether the authentication of both credentials were successful.
segment.target: The identity provider returns an authentication status that indicates whether the authentication of both credentials were successful.

segment.source: If successful, data exchange begins.
segment.target: If successful, data exchange begins.

segment.source: Otherwise, the user must be re-authenticated.
segment.target: Otherwise, the user must be re-authenticated.

segment.target: two-factor authentication

segment.source: As you can see, this process also differs from single-factor authentication in that the second user credential is sent to the user instead of being created or provided by the user.
segment.target: As you can see, this process also differs from single-factor authentication in that the second user credential is sent to the user instead of being created or provided by the user.

segment.source: The user is therefore not in complete control of the necessary credentials.
segment.target: The user is therefore not in complete control of the necessary credentials.

segment.source: This also applies when a smart card is used as the second credential: the organization is in charge of creating and providing it to the user.

segment.source: 2.2.1 Azure Active Directory
segment.target: 2.2.1 Azure Active Directory

segment.source: Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) is a cloud-based identity and access management service that can serve as the identity provider in single-factor or multi-factor authentication.
segment.target: Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) is a cloud-based identity and access management service that can serve as the identity provider in single-factor or multi-factor authentication.

segment.source: Azure AD authentication can be used with or without a verification code.
segment.target: Azure AD authentication can be used with or without a verification code.

segment.source: While Azure AD can also implement single-factor authentication, enterprises usually require the higher security of multi-factor authentication.
segment.target: While Azure AD can also implement single-factor authentication, enterprises usually require the higher security of multi-factor authentication.

segment.source: In a multi-factor authentication configuration, a user authenticating with an Azure AD account has the option of having a verification code sent as an SMS message either to their mobile phone or the Azure Authenticator mobile app.
segment.target: In a multi-factor authentication configuration, a user authenticating with an Azure AD account has the option of having a verification code sent as an SMS message either to their mobile phone or the Azure Authenticator mobile app.

segment.source: Additionally, Azure AD can be used as an OAuth provider, providing the standard user with an authentication and authorization mechanism to apps across various platforms.
segment.target: Additionally, Azure AD can be used as an OAuth provider, providing the standard user with an authentication and authorization mechanism to apps across various platforms.

segment.source: To learn more, see Azure Active Directory and Multi-Factor Authentication on Azure.
segment.target: To learn more, see Azure Active Directory and Multi-Factor Authentication on Azure.

segment.source: 2.4 Microsoft Passport and Windows Hello
segment.target: 2.4 Microsoft Passport and Windows Hello

segment.source: In Windows 10, a convenient multi-factor authentication mechanism is built into the operating system.
segment.target: In Windows 10, a convenient multi-factor authentication mechanism is built into the operating system.

segment.source: The two components involved are called Microsoft Passport and Windows Hello.
segment.target: The two components involved are called Microsoft Passport and Windows Hello.

segment.source: Windows Hello is the new biometric sign-in system built into Windows 10.
segment.target: Windows Hello is the new biometric sign-in system built into Windows 10.

segment.source: Because it is built directly into the operating system, Windows Hello allows face or fingerprint identification to unlock users’ devices.
segment.target: Because it is built directly into the operating system, Windows Hello allows face or fingerprint identification to unlock users’ devices.

segment.source: The Windows secure credential store protects biometric data on the device.
segment.target: The Windows secure credential store protects biometric data on the device.

segment.source: Windows Hello provides a robust way for a device to recognize an individual user, which addresses the first part of the path between a user and a requested service or data item.
segment.target: Windows Hello provides a robust way for a device to recognize an individual user, which addresses the first part of the path between a user and a requested service or data item.

segment.source: After the device has recognized the user, it still must authenticate the user before determining whether to grant access to a requested resource.
segment.target: After the device has recognized the user, it still must authenticate the user before determining whether to grant access to a requested resource.

segment.source: Microsoft Passport provides strong two-factor authentication (2FA) that is fully integrated into Windows and replaces reusable passwords with the combination of a specific device, and a biometric gesture or PIN.
segment.target: Microsoft Passport provides strong two-factor authentication (2FA) that is fully integrated into Windows and replaces reusable passwords with the combination of a specific device, and a biometric gesture or PIN.

segment.source: The PIN is specified by the user as part of their Microsoft Passport enrollment.
segment.target: The PIN is specified by the user as part of their Microsoft Passport enrollment.

segment.source: Microsoft Passport isn’t just a replacement for traditional 2FA systems, though.
segment.target: Microsoft Passport isn’t just a replacement for traditional 2FA systems, though.

segment.source: It’s conceptually similar to smart cards: authentication is performed by using cryptographic primitives instead of string comparisons, and the user’s key material is secure inside tamper-resistant hardware.
segment.target: It’s conceptually similar to smart cards: authentication is performed by using cryptographic primitives instead of string comparisons, and the user’s key material is secure inside tamper-resistant hardware.

segment.source: Microsoft Passport doesn’t require the extra infrastructure components required for smart card deployment, either.
segment.target: Microsoft Passport doesn’t require the extra infrastructure components required for smart card deployment, either.

segment.source: In particular, you don’t need a Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) to manage certificates, if you don’t currently have one.
segment.target: In particular, you don’t need a Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) to manage certificates, if you don’t currently have one.

segment.source: Microsoft Passport combines the major advantages of smart cards—deployment flexibility for virtual smart cards and robust security for physical smart cards—without any of their drawbacks.
segment.target: Microsoft Passport combines the major advantages of smart cards—deployment flexibility for virtual smart cards and robust security for physical smart cards—without any of their drawbacks.

segment.source: A device must be registered with Microsoft Passport before users can authenticate with it.
segment.target: A device must be registered with Microsoft Passport before users can authenticate with it.

segment.source: Microsoft Passport uses asymmetric (public/private key) encryption in which one party uses a public key to encrypt the data that the other party can decrypt using a private key.
segment.target: Microsoft Passport uses asymmetric (public/private key) encryption in which one party uses a public key to encrypt the data that the other party can decrypt using a private key.

segment.source: In the case of Microsoft Passport, it creates a set of public/private key pairs and writes the private keys to the device’s Trusted Platform Module (TPM) chip.
segment.target: In the case of Microsoft Passport, it creates a set of public/private key pairs and writes the private keys to the device’s Trusted Platform Module (TPM) chip.

segment.target: After a device has been registered, UWP apps can call system APIs to retrieve the user’s public key, which can be used to register the user on the server.

segment.source: 3 Data-in-flight security methods
segment.target: 3 Data-in-flight security methods

segment.source: Data-in-flight security methods apply to data in transit between devices connected to a network.

segment.source: 3.1 Remote system authentication

segment.target: We’ll discuss two requirements for secure remote system communication.

segment.source: The first requirement is message confidentiality: The information passed between the client and the web services (for example, the identity of the user and other personal information) must not be readable by third parties while in transit.
segment.target: The first requirement is message confidentiality: The information passed between the client and the web services (for example, the identity of the user and other personal information) must not be readable by third parties while in transit.

segment.source: This is usually accomplished by encrypting the connection over which messages are sent and by encrypting the message itself.

segment.source: The second requirement is message integrity: The client and the web service must be able to verify that the messages they receive are the ones intended to be sent by the other party, and that the message has not been altered in transit.
segment.target: The second requirement is message integrity: The client and the web service must be able to verify that the messages they receive are the ones intended to be sent by the other party, and that the message has not been altered in transit.

segment.source: 3.2.1 SSL pinning
segment.target: 3.2.1 SSL pinning

segment.source: To prevent this, a technique called SSL pinning is used to verify that the certificate on the server is the certificate that the client expects and trusts.

segment.source: 4.1 Windows app model
segment.target: 4.1 Windows app model

segment.source: Traditionally, Windows has never had a definition of an app.

segment.source: It was most commonly referred to as an executable (.exe), and this never included installation, storage of state, execution length, versioning, OS integration, or app-to-app communication.
segment.target: It was most commonly referred to as an executable (.exe), and this never included installation, storage of state, execution length, versioning, OS integration, or app-to-app communication.

segment.source: The Universal Windows Platform model defines an app model that covers installation, runtime environment, resource management, updates, data model, and uninstallation.
segment.target: The Universal Windows Platform model defines an app model that covers installation, runtime environment, resource management, updates, data model, and uninstallation.

segment.source: Windows 10 apps run in a container, which means that they have limited privileges by default (additional privileges can be requested and granted by the user).
segment.target: Windows 10 apps run in a container, which means that they have limited privileges by default (additional privileges can be requested and granted by the user).

segment.source: For example, if an app wants to access files on the system, a file picker from the Windows.Storage.Pickers namespace has to be used to let the user pick a file (no direct access to files is enabled).
segment.target: For example, if an app wants to access files on the system, a file picker from the Windows.Storage.Pickers namespace has to be used to let the user pick a file (no direct access to files is enabled).

segment.source: 4.3 Stored data protection
segment.target: 4.3 Stored data protection

segment.source: When you are dealing with stored data, commonly referred to as data-at-rest, encrypting it can prevent unauthorized users from accessing the stored data.
segment.target: When you are dealing with stored data, commonly referred to as data-at-rest, encrypting it can prevent unauthorized users from accessing the stored data.

segment.source: The two common mechanisms to encrypt data are using either symmetric keys or using asymmetric keys.
segment.target: The two common mechanisms to encrypt data are using either symmetric keys or using asymmetric keys.

segment.source: However, data encryption can’t ensure that the data is unaltered between the time it was sent and the time it was stored.
segment.target: However, data encryption can’t ensure that the data is unaltered between the time it was sent and the time it was stored.

segment.source: In other words, the data integrity cannot be ensured.
segment.target: In other words, the data integrity cannot be ensured.

segment.source: Using message authentication codes, hashes, and digital signing are common techniques to solve this problem.
segment.target: Using message authentication codes, hashes, and digital signing are common techniques to solve this problem.

segment.source: 4.3.1 Data encryption
segment.target: 4.3.1 Data encryption

segment.source: With symmetric encryption, both the sender and recipient have the same key and use it to both encrypt and decrypt the data.
segment.target: With symmetric encryption, both the sender and recipient have the same key and use it to both encrypt and decrypt the data.

segment.source: The challenge with this approach is securely sharing the key so both parties are aware of it.
segment.target: The challenge with this approach is securely sharing the key so both parties are aware of it.

segment.source: One answer to this is asymmetric encryption, in which a public/private key pair is used.
segment.target: One answer to this is asymmetric encryption, in which a public/private key pair is used.

segment.source: The public key is shared freely with anyone who wants to encrypt a message.
segment.target: The public key is shared freely with anyone who wants to encrypt a message.

segment.source: The private key is always kept secret so that only you can use it to decrypt the data.
segment.target: The private key is always kept secret so that only you can use it to decrypt the data.

segment.source: A common technique to allow for discovery of the public key is by using digital certificates, also simply referred to as certificates.
segment.target: A common technique to allow for discovery of the public key is by using digital certificates, also simply referred to as certificates.

segment.source: The certificate holds information about the public key, in addition to information about the user or server such as the name, issuer, email address and country.
segment.target: The certificate holds information about the public key, in addition to information about the user or server such as the name, issuer, email address and country.

segment.target: Windows app developers can use the SymmetricKeyAlgorithmProvider and AsymmetricKeyAlgorithmProvider classes to implement symmetric and asymmetric encryption in their UWP apps.

segment.source: 4.3 Detecting message tampering (MACs, hashes, and signatures)
segment.target: 4.3 Detecting message tampering (MACs, hashes, and signatures)

segment.source: A MAC is a code (or tag) that results from using a symmetric key (called the secret key) or a message as input to a MAC encryption algorithm.
segment.target: A MAC is a code (or tag) that results from using a symmetric key (called the secret key) or a message as input to a MAC encryption algorithm.

segment.source: The secret key and the algorithm are agreed upon by the sender and receiver before the message transfer.
segment.target: The secret key and the algorithm are agreed upon by the sender and receiver before the message transfer.

segment.source: MACs verify messages like this.
segment.target: MACs verify messages like this.

segment.source: The sender derives the MAC tag by using the secret key as input to the MAC algorithm.
segment.target: The sender derives the MAC tag by using the secret key as input to the MAC algorithm.

segment.source: The sender sends the MAC tag and the message to the receiver.
segment.target: The sender sends the MAC tag and the message to the receiver.

segment.source: The receiver derives the MAC tag by using the secret key and the message as inputs to the MAC algorithm.
segment.target: The receiver derives the MAC tag by using the secret key and the message as inputs to the MAC algorithm.

segment.source: The receiver compares their MAC tag with the sender's MAC tag.
segment.target: The receiver compares their MAC tag with the sender's MAC tag.

segment.source: If they are the same then we know that the message has not been tampered with.
segment.target: If they are the same then we know that the message has not been tampered with.

segment.target: Windows apps can implement MAC message verification by calling the MacAlgorithmProvider class to generate the key and CryptographicEngine class to perform the MAC encryption algorithm.

segment.source: 4.3.1 Using hashes
segment.target: 4.3.1 Using hashes

segment.source: There is an entire family of hash functions that can do this.

segment.source: 4.3.2 Digital signatures
segment.target: 4.3.2 Digital signatures

segment.source: The data integrity of a digitally signed stored message is verified in a similar way to MAC authentication.
segment.target: The data integrity of a digitally signed stored message is verified in a similar way to MAC authentication.

segment.source: Here is the way the digital signature workflow operates.
segment.target: Here is the way the digital signature workflow operates.

segment.source: The sender derives a hash value (also known as a digest) by using the message as the input to a hash algorithm.
segment.target: The sender derives a hash value (also known as a digest) by using the message as the input to a hash algorithm.

segment.source: The sender encrypts the digest using their private key.
segment.target: The sender encrypts the digest using their private key.

segment.source: The sender sends the message, the encrypted digest, and the name of the hash algorithm that was used.
segment.target: The sender sends the message, the encrypted digest, and the name of the hash algorithm that was used.

segment.source: The receiver uses the public key to decrypt the encrypted digest it received.
segment.target: The receiver uses the public key to decrypt the encrypted digest it received.

segment.source: It then uses the hash algorithm to hash the message to create a digest of its own.
segment.target: It then uses the hash algorithm to hash the message to create a digest of its own.

segment.source: And finally the receiver compares the two digests (the one it received and decrypted, and the one it made).
segment.target: And finally the receiver compares the two digests (the one it received and decrypted, and the one it made).

segment.source: Only if the two match can the receiver be sure that the message was sent by the possessor of the private key, and therefore they are who they say they are, and that the message was not altered in transit.
segment.target: Only if the two match can the receiver be sure that the message was sent by the possessor of the private key, and therefore they are who they say they are, and that the message was not altered in transit.

segment.source: The resulting hash value is an arbitrary length and can be shorter than the full message, so using public and private keys to encrypt and decrypt only the digest rather than the full message is an optimization.
segment.target: The resulting hash value is an arbitrary length and can be shorter than the full message, so using public and private keys to encrypt and decrypt only the digest rather than the full message is an optimization.

segment.source: 5 Summary
segment.target: 5 Summary

segment.source: The Universal Windows Platform in Windows 10 offers a number of ways to leverage operating system capabilities to create more secure apps.
segment.target: The Universal Windows Platform in Windows 10 offers a number of ways to leverage operating system capabilities to create more secure apps.

segment.source: In different authentication scenarios, such as single-factor, multi-factor, or brokered authentication with an OAuth identity provider, APIs exist to mitigate the most common challenges with authentication.
segment.target: In different authentication scenarios, such as single-factor, multi-factor, or brokered authentication with an OAuth identity provider, APIs exist to mitigate the most common challenges with authentication.

segment.source: Windows Hello provides a new biometric sign-in system that recognizes the user and actively defeats efforts to circumvent proper identification.
segment.target: Windows Hello provides a new biometric sign-in system that recognizes the user and actively defeats efforts to circumvent proper identification.

segment.source: Microsoft Passport works with Windows Hello to deliver multiple layers of keys and certificates that can never be revealed or used outside the trusted platform module.
segment.target: Microsoft Passport works with Windows Hello to deliver multiple layers of keys and certificates that can never be revealed or used outside the trusted platform module.

segment.source: Plus, a further layer of security is available through the optional use of attestation identity keys and certificates.
segment.target: Plus, a further layer of security is available through the optional use of attestation identity keys and certificates.

segment.source: To secure data in flight, APIs exist to communicate with remote systems securely over SSL, while providing the possibility to validate the server’s authenticity with SSL pinning.
segment.target: To secure data in flight, APIs exist to communicate with remote systems securely over SSL, while providing the possibility to validate the server’s authenticity with SSL pinning.

segment.source: Publishing APIs securely and in a controlled manner is something in which Azure API Management aids by providing powerful configuration options for exposing APIs across the web using a proxy that provides additional obfuscation of the API endpoint.
segment.target: Publishing APIs securely and in a controlled manner is something in which Azure API Management aids by providing powerful configuration options for exposing APIs across the web using a proxy that provides additional obfuscation of the API endpoint.

segment.source: Access to these APIs is secured by using API keys and API calls can be throttled to control performance.
segment.target: Access to these APIs is secured by using API keys and API calls can be throttled to control performance.

segment.source: When the data arrives on the device, the Windows app model provides more control over how the app is installed, updated and accesses it data, while keeping it from accessing data of other apps in an unauthorized manner.
segment.target: When the data arrives on the device, the Windows app model provides more control over how the app is installed, updated and accesses it data, while keeping it from accessing data of other apps in an unauthorized manner.

segment.source: Credential locker can provide secure storage of user credentials that is managed by the operating system and other data can be protected on the device by using the encryption and hashing APIs offered by the Universal Windows Platform.
segment.target: Credential locker can provide secure storage of user credentials that is managed by the operating system and other data can be protected on the device by using the encryption and hashing APIs offered by the Universal Windows Platform.
